Award.AwardTitle: Molecule-surface scattering with velocity controlled molecular beams
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this award, funded by the Experimental Physical Chemistry Program of the Division of Chemistry, Professor Alec Wodtke of the University of California - Santa Barbara, together with his graduate students, will investigate the collisions of excited CO molecules colliding with a gold [Au(111)] surface. This research coordinates with a collaborative award funded by the Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft (DFG) to Dr. Gerard Meijer from the Department of Molecular Physics, Fritz Haber Institute of the Max Planck Society. This collaborative project combines the expertise of the Meijer group in accelerating/decelerating molecular beams to well-defined velocities (via Stark velocity control) with the Wodtke group's expertise in molecular beam-surface scattering to investigate energy transfer in molecule-surface scattering with unprecedented control.

Gas-surface interactions are important in a number of areas, from heterogeneous catalysis to atmospheric chemistry. Developing an understanding of these processes requires not only understanding how reactions occur at surfaces, but also how energy is transferred between the surface and the gas phase. The goal of work like that of Prof. Wodtke is to develop a better understanding of how energy is transferred from gas-phase species to a surface. Recent work out of the Wodtke laboratory shows that previous theoretical models are incomplete. In addition to the broader scientific impact of the proposed research work, Prof. Wodtke's students will receive significant exposure to one of the finest Chemical Physics laboratories in Germany -- training a new group of globally-engaged scientists in the United States.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We have used the Stark deceleration method for the first time in surface scattering experiments. Two fields have thus been merged in a new experimental concept.  The Stark deceleration method allows us to control the velocities of molecules beams. Incidence velocities are as low as 50 meter per second, there speed of a NASCAR Racing vehicle. While this sounds still very fast, typical molecules fly with speeds typically 100 times faster. Thus we are able to examine the nature of very slow moving molecules. Our new instrument uses these slow moving molecules to collide with a well characterized single crystal metal surface. This required great experimental expertise to combine the two methods of velocity controlled beams with surface science methods. Hence the major outcome of this work is the instrument itself. We are now beginning the first work on scientific problems with this instrument. We have examined the velocity dependence and the surface temperature dependence of the electronic quenching of electronically excited carbon monoxide colliding with a gold surface. Initial results reveal a marked surface temperature dependence (enhancement with increased Ts) and an approximate independence if quenching with velocity. We also see that the quenching efficiency depends on the vibrational excitation of the electronically excited carbon monoxide molecules. This appears in a very peculiar way in the time dependence of the electron emission signal.
